attributes.title: Choosing to Get Perspective: How Does a Monetary Incentive Influence Selection of Questions and Accuracy of Predictions?
attributes.description: In this study, participants (predictors) will be asked to predict another person’s (i.e., a pre-recorded video of a target) responses to a series of opinion statements. After making their predictions, they will be asked to indicate the degree to which they are confident in the accuracy of their predictions. We will examine whether receiving (vs. not) a monetary incentive, depending on the accuracy of their predictions, will influence the number of items that predictors will choose to ask the target.

q2.value:
We hypothesize that accuracy of opinion predictions for another person will be the highest when participants directly get another student’s perspective on all of the questionnaire’s items (PG_All) and when they will be given an incentive to be accurate (i.e., for every item they predict correctly) as they choose which – and how many – items they want to discuss (PG_Choice_I), followed by those who are not given an incentive when choosing the items they want to discuss (PG_Choice_NI). Lastly, we predict that accuracy will be lowest for participants in the Control condition.

While we did not find, in our previous study, that participants’ accuracy was a function of the number of items they chose to get the other student’s perspective on, we expect to find, in the current study, that there will be a relation between their accuracy and the number of items they choose. We believe that our previous finding may be due to the fact that the items in the self-report questionnaires were highly correlated with one another. Thus, we would expect to find that the number of items chosen on a questionnaire with more variability in the items, such as the one in the current study, would be a function of accuracy.

We predict that participants will report having been the most motivated to make accurate predictions in the incentivized condition (i.e., PG_Choice_I).

While we do not have a clear prediction regarding which participants will be more or less confident overall in the accuracy of their predictions or which participants will be more/less overconfident (their expected number of correct predictions compared to the actual number of items they predicted correctly), we expect to find overconfidence across all four strategy conditions.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We will employ a one-way ANOVA, with 4 levels (between-subjects factor).

Specifically, participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions: 1) Perspective Getting – Choice, Incentivized (PG_CI) -- where predictors will first be told that they will be monetarily rewarded for the accuracy of their predictions and will then choose which items they’d like to “ask” the target, before asking them; 2) Perspective Getting – Choice, Not Incentivized (PG_CNI) -- predictors will indicate which items they’d like to ask and then ask the target, without receiving any prior motivation for making accurate predictions; 3) Perspective Getting – All (PG_A) -- wherein predictors will get the target’s perspective for all of the items on the direct questionnaire, prior to making their predictions; or 4) Control -- predictors will be told to use whichever strategy they’d like when making their predictions for the target, without further instruction.

q7.value:
We will use simple randomization, where each predictor will be randomly assigned to one of the four strategy conditions. The strategy condition that predictors will be assigned to will be determined prior to their participation in the study, as it will be randomly listed on the sheet the experimenters will record information on (subject number, etc.). Moreover, simple randomization will be used for assigning which target (and their videos) the predictor will be "paired" with and subsequently make predictions for.

The items in the direct questionnaire that predictors will answer and make predictions on will be randomized within the block, using Qualtrics' software.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: Access to the data has been limited and has not yet been looked at by anyone. We have started recording the videos of the participants ("targets"), which will be shown to participants ("predictors") in the main study. The predictors will watch one target's videos and make predictions about that target's opinions on a questionnaire.

question.value: Participants will be recruited via various Facebook groups whose members are students at the University. Videos of the participants are being recorded via the online video communications platform Zoom, and then answer a questionnaire and additional questions via a Qualtrics link. Participants ("predictors") in the main part of the study will access the study online via a Qualtrics link. Participations will be paid the equivalent of about 6 USD (with participants in the incentivized condition having the opportunity to earn up to 6 USD more, depending on the number of correct predictions they make). Participants must be at least 18 years old and native Hebrew speakers (as the study will be conducted in Israel).

q11.value: The sample size of the study will be 256 participants (with 64 participants per condition). However, for robustness purposes, I will use a sample size of 264 (with 66 participants per condition), in the case that participants need to be excluded. The number of "targets" that we are recruiting is 88, so that each target's set of videos is viewed by three (randomly assigned) "predictors".

q12.value: The sample size is based on a medium effect size (.17) and a power of .80.

question.value:
Accuracy of predictions: We will be measuring the accuracy of participants’ predictions for another student in the study. Specifically, participants will complete the everyday opinions questionnaire once for themselves and will then make their predictions for the other student on this measure. We will use these ratings to measure the difference between their predictions for the other student and that student’s actual responses, as well as the correlation between their predictions and the student’s actual responses on the questionnaire. We will also measure the actual number of items that participants predicted exactly correct for the other student.

Confidence: Participants will rate how confident they are (using a 7-point Likert scale) in the overall accuracy of their predictions for the other student on the questionnaire. Moreover, we will ask participants twice (once before completing the study and once after making their predictions) to provide a number between 0 and 20 (i.e., the questionnaire includes 20 items), indicating their confidence in the exact number of items they predicted for their partner correctly.

Over-confidence: As mentioned previously, participants will be asked to provide a number (between 0 and 20), indicating the exact number of items on the questionnaire that they are confident in predicting exactly correct for the other student. We will then calculate the difference between this number and the actual number of items that participants predicted exactly correctly, to assess over-confidence.

To assess the accuracy hypotheses:
Analyzing accuracy of predictions using 1) absolute difference scores, 2) correlations, and 3) actual number of items predicted correctly with an ANOVA, I will test differences in accuracy for the strategy conditions and the exact number of items that participants accurately predict for the other student.

To test the hypothesis regarding number of chosen items being a function of accuracy:
Use a linear regression analysis to test whether the number of items chosen by participants in the two choice conditions is a function of accuracy.

To test the motivation hypothesis:
Use an ANOVA to analyze participants’ self-reported level of motivation to be accurate when they made their predictions for the other student.

To test the confidence hypothesis:
Use a series of ANOVAs to test whether overall confidence in predictions varies by strategy condition.

To test the over-confidence hypothesis:
Use a general linear model to test whether confidence judgments differ across the four strategy conditions

q20.value: Participants will be excluded, should they decide to end their participation in the experimental session before completing the whole study. Data may also be excluded due to experimenter error (e.g., equipment malfunction). Otherwise, all data will be retained and analyzed.

q22.value:
We will test whether participants in the four strategy conditions differ in their level of projection (to what extent their responses for themselves on the measures are similar to their predictions for the other student).

We will also test whether a) perceived similarity between participants in each dyad influences accuracy of predictions, b) accuracy is affected by how honest participants believe the other student was when discussing their perspective, c) whether there are differences in participants’ self-reported honesty, d) how comfortable participants would feel discussing their opinions with another student, f) how “good” people believe themselves to be at intuiting another person’s opinions, f) how much the participant feels similar to the other student, and g) how much they like the other student.

q23.value: In the main study, participants in all conditions will watch a prerecorded video of another student introducing themselves. In addition, all participants, except for those in the Control condition, will have the opportunity to get the student’s perspective via prerecorded clips on the various opinions listed in the questionnaire. Before we conduct the main study, we are recruiting 88 students and are video recording their responses to the various opinion statements on the questionnaire. In order to calculate participants’ accuracy in the main study, we are asking the recorded students to fill out the everyday opinions questionnaire for themselves, as well as additional questions gauging: how many opinion statements they believe they would predict exactly correctly for another student, their own honesty in their videotaped responses, their general ability to accurately intuit others’ opinions, how comfortable they would feel discussing their opinions with another student, how honest they believe another student would be in a discussion with them regarding their opinions, and how motivated they would be to make accurate predictions regarding another student.

attributes.title: Do the Spatial and Kinematic Properties of Facial Expressions Influence Emotion Recognition in Autism Spectrum Disorders?
attributes.description:
Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder, characterized by difficutlies in social communication, and restricted and repetitive interests (American Psychiatric Association, 2013). Given that the ability to infer emotion from facial expressions is crucial for social interaction, emotion recognition has long been suspected to be a core difficulty within ASD (Hobson, 1986). However, whilst many studies suggest a disparity in the facial expression recognition ability of autistic and neurotypical individuals (Ashwin, Chapman, Colle, & Baron‐Cohen, 2006; Dziobek, Bahnemann, Convit, & Heekeren, 2010; Lindner & Rosén, 2006; Philip et al., 2010), there have been inconsistent findings, ranging from no differences between autistic and neurotypical individuals to large disparities (see Keating & Cook, in press, and Uljarevic & Hamilton, 2012 for reviews). Despite these inconsistencies, the evidence largely suggests that there are differences in facial expression recognition between autistic and neurotypical individuals. 

Only recently has there been a shift towards using dynamic depictions of faces (which include kinematic information) as opposed to static stimuli to assess facial expression recognition. Indeed, studies that employ dynamic tasks are profoundly under-represented in meta-analyses investigating the emotion recognition of autistic individuals (Keating & Cook, in press.). This may be problematic given that naturally occurring facial expressions are inherently dynamic, and therefore may have greater ecological validity (Uljarevic & Hamiltom, 2013; Krumhuber, Kappas & Manstead, 2013). Amongst the few studies that have examined the influence of facial movement kinematics on emotion perception, there is a consensus that there are differences between autistic and neurotypical individuals. For instance, Sato and colleagues (2013) found that autistic children were more likely to rate slow-moving morphs as ‘natural’ looking than neurotypical children. Another study had a professional actress display emotional (joy, surprise, sadness and disgust), and non-emotional (porunication of A, O, I, and tongue protrusion) expressions slowly (Tardif et al., 2008). The speed of these videos were then manipulated to give three conditions (very-slow, slow, and normal). Importantly, in their post-hoc analyses, Tardif and colleagues (2008) identified that the autistic individuals had superior emotion recognition in the slow relative to the normal speed condition. 

The findings of these behavioural investigations resonate well with those from neurophysiological studies. Generally, this literature suggests that autistic individuals, relative to neurotypicals, exhibit slowed processing of static face images as indexed by N170 latency (see Kang et al., 2018 for a summary). As a whole, the evidence suggests that autistic individuals may experience improved emotion recognition for slow moving faces. However, more research employing dynamic stimuli is necessary to confirm the assertion that autistic individuals have better emotion recognition for slowed facial stimuli. 

A parallel literature concerns emotion recognition from body movements. Here it has been suggested that kinematic aspects of bodily movement contribute to emotion recognition, and may underpin the differences in emotion recognition between autistic and neurotypical individuals. Indeed evidence of this comes from studies using point-light displays (PLD)- a set of moving dots that convey biological motion. One study manipulated these PLDs in terms of acceleration and had participants rate the naturalness of the displayed movements (Lee & Chang, 2019). This study found a robust association between performance on this biological motion naturalness task and attention switching domain scores on the AQ (Lee & Chang, 2019). Therefore, it seems that kinematics may be implicated in the emotion recognition differences between those high and low in ASD traits. 

Indeed, recent developments in the face processing literature emphasize the importance of kinematic cues in emotion recognition. One study demonstrated this by utilisng point-light displays of the face (known as PLFs) which had been manipulated to achieve three spatial levels (S1 – 50% spatial; S2 – 100%; S3 – 150%) and three kinematic levels (K1 – 50% speed; K2 – 100%; K3 – 150%) (Sowden et al., under review). This study revealed that intensity ratings, given by neurotypical participants, were modulated as a function of both spatial and kinematic cues. Specifically, at the S1 and K1 levels (i.e. with less spatial movement/ lower speed), participants rated the PLFs as more intensely sad, and less intensely angry and happy, and at the S3 and K3 levels (i.e. with  more spatial movement/ greater speed), they rated the PLFs as less intensely sad, and more intensely angry and happy (Sowden et al., under review). This novel PLF task has great utility for investigating facial expression recognition as it eliminates contrast, texture, colour and luminance cues (e.g. a flushed face or tears), and other information (e.g. identity) that can be seen in photograph stimuli. Hence, this task allows us to investigate the importance of the kinematic and spatial aspects of facial expressions without these factors confounding the results. To the best of our knowledge it is also the first task which can index independent contributions of both spatial and kinematic cues in facial emotion recognition. Therefore, the present study will utilise dynamic face stimuli, that have been manipulated kinematially and spatially (Sowden et al., under review) to identify whether, compared to neurotypical individuals, those with ASD exhibit differences in processing the kinematic and/or spatial properties of facial expressions.

Alexithymia
When discussing the facial expression recognition of autistic individuals, it is also crucial to consider the role of alexithymia. Alexithymia is a subclinical condition characterized by difficulties identifying and expressing emotions (Kooiman, Spinhoven & Trijsburg, 2002). Whilst the incidence of alexithymia in the neurotypical population is 13% (Salminen et al., 1999), in the autistic population these rates are elevated, with 40- 65% of autistic adults meeting criteria (Berthoz & Hill, 2005; Hill, Berthoz & Frith, 2004). 

Whilst some research has suggested that autistic individuals exhibit differences relative to neurotypicals in recognizing others’ emotion, there are considerable individual differences – not everyone with an autism diagnosis exhibit face processing differences (Harms, Martin & Wallace, 2010; Uljarevic & Hamilton, 2012). It has been proposed that alexithymia, and not autistic traits, may account for the reported impairments in facial emotion recognition, and this could explain the inconsistencies in previous research (Bird and Cook, 2013). Indeed the “alexithymia hypothesis” (Bird and Cook, 2013) postulates that alexithymia underpins the individual differences in emotion processing that are seen in the ASD population such that intact emotion recognition is typical in individuals that have an autism diagnosis without co-ocurring alexithymia . Indeed, this hypothesis is supported by the finding that there are no differences in facial expression recognition between autistic participants and neurotypicals when the two groups are matched in terms of alexithymia (Cook, Brewer, Shah, & Bird, 2013). Moreover when the variables of this study were examined continuously, it was found that possessing alexithymic traits, but not autistic traits, was predictive of poorer performance on emotion recognition and empathy tasks (Cook, Brewer, Shah, & Bird, 2013). Thus overall, it appears that alexithymia is heavily implicated in differences in facial expression recognition that are commonly (but not universally) documented within ASD populations. 

The current study
First participants will complete various questionnaires including the Autism Quotient (AQ; Baron-Cohen, et al., 2006), and the Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS; Bagby, et al., 1994). Next, participants will complete Sowden et al’s (under review) facial expression recognition task. In this task, participants will rate PLF (point-light face) stimuli regarding the extent to which they appear happy, angry and sad. These PLFs vary in emotion (happy, angry and sad), and have been adapted to achieve three spatial movement levels (S1 – 50% spatial movement; S2 – 100%; S3 – 150%) and three kinematic (speed) levels (K1 – 50% speed; K2 – 100%; K3 – 150%). Then, participants will complete two adapted PLF tasks in which they rate the naturalness of facial expressions that have been manipulated spatially and kinematically. Finally, participants will complete the Matrix Reasoning Item Bank (MaRs-IB; Chierchia et al. 2019), which assesses non-verbal reasoning.

q1.value: Connor Keating, Sophie Sowden, Jennifer Cook

q2.value:
There are a number of hypotheses that are relevant to the upcoming study:

ANOVAs: In order to replicate the findings in Sowden et al., (under review) data from neurotpyical participants will be analysed with a repeated measures 3x3x3 ANOVA with the factors emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus kinematic level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3). This ANOVA will be run with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. We here focus our predictions on the primary effects of importance from Sowden et al., (under review). We predict an interaction between emotion and spatial level such that facial expression recognition accuracy will be enhanced at the S3 level (relative to the S1 and S2 level) for the happy and angry expressions, but lower for sad expressions (as sad expressions with increased movement may appear angry). In contrast, facial expression recognition accuracy will be enhanced at the S1 level for sad expression, but diminished for happy and angry expressions (as sad expressions with less movement look more intensely sad leading to enhanced accuracy). Furthermore, we predict an interaction between emotion and kinematic level such that facial expression recognition accuracy will be elevated at the K3 level (relatvie to K1 and K2) for happy and angry expressions, but lower for sad expressions (as sad expressions with increased speed may look angry). Conversely, we predict that at the K1 level (relative to K2 and K3), facial expression recognition accuracy will be elevated for sad expressions, but lower for angry and sad (as when sad expressions are slowed down they look more intensely sad). These predictions are made on the basis of findings from Sowden et al., (under review).

In addition, this task will bring novel insight by analysing the recognition task data with a mixed 2x3x3x3 ANOVA with the factors group (ASD vs. control), emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus kinematic level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3). This ANOVA will be run with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. In this analysis we predict a main effect of group such that the ASD group will have significantly lower facial expression recognition accuracy than controls. It is unclear whether facial expression recognition differences are due to difficulties processing spatial or kinematic properties of faces and therefore we will explore whether the group main effect is modulated by an interaction with spatial and/or kinematic level.

Mutliple Regression Analysis: The facial expression recognition data will be analysed using a multiple regression analysis across both groups. We hypothesize that alexithymic traits will account for more variance than autistic traits with respect to facial expression recognition accuracy.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study employs a mixed design with a between-subjects factor of ASD diagnosis (ASD diagnosis or neurotypical) and where all participants will participate in every condition of the independent variables. Participants will complete all of the following tasks online in light of the recent COVID-19 outbreak.
 
First participants will complete various questionnaires including the Autism Quotient (AQ; Baron-Cohen, et al., 2006), and the Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS; Bagby, et al., 1994). In addition, an ADOS-2 assessment will be completed only in the ASD group to verify ASD diagnosis. 

Next, participants will complete the facial expression recognition task. This involves participants rating PLF (point-light face) stimuli (created from 4 actors verbalising sentences whilst posing emotional states) on a visual analogue scale according to how happy, angry and sad they appear. These PLFs vary in emotion (happy, angry and sad), and have been adapted to achieve three spatial movement levels (S1 – 50% spatial movement; S2 – 100%; S3 – 150%) and three kinematic levels (K1 – 50% speed; K2 – 100%; K3 – 150%) resulting in 9 manipulations per emotion (e.g. (1) S1, K1, (2) S2, K1, (3) S3, K1, (4) S1, K2, (5) S2, K2, (6) S3, K2, (7) S1, K3, (8), S2, K3, (9) S3, K3). This task was developed by Sowden et al. (under review).

Participants will then complete another shorter facial expression recognition task. This involves participants rating PLF stimuli according to how natural the facial expressions appear on a visual analogue scale. These PLFs vary in emotion (happy, angry and sad) and have been adapted to include three spatial movment levels (S1 – 50% spatial movement; S2 – 100%; S3 – 150). After rating face stimuli that vary in their spatial movement, participants will be shown PLFs displaying the target emotions that have been adapted to include three kinematic levels (K1 – 50% speed; K2 – 100%; K3 – 150%). These are included for exploratory purposes due to reports of differences in naturalness ratings between autistic and neurotypical participants (Sato et al., 2013). 

Finally, participants will complete the Matrix Reasoning Item Bank (MaRs-IB; Chierchia et al. 2019), which assesses non-verbal reasoning.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants aged 18-65, will be recruited to take part in the study. ASD participants will be recruited via an existing Autism Research Database by email, Prolific and social media (e.g. Facebook). Participants may also be recruited via the Autistica Discover Network. Neurotypical participants will be recruited via an existing Control Participant Database, Prolific and social media (e.g. Facebook). All recruitment material contains information about the study, reimbursement and inclusion criteria. Informed consent will be given by all participants, who will be reimbursed with payment at a rate of £10 per hour. The study has received approval from the STEM Ethics Committee at the University of Birmingham (ERN_16-0281AP9A) and from the Birmingham Participatory Autism Research Team (B-PART) Consultancy group.

q11.value: 30 ASD participants and 30 NT participants will be recruited to participate in the study. Participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal vision.

q12.value:
The chosen sample size is based on a power analysis conducted using GLIMMPSE (Kriedler et al. 2013), which focuses on replicating the primary results in the neurotypical group (emotion * spatial, emotion * kinematic interactions). Using data from a pilot study (Sowden et al., under review), 8 participants are required in the NT group in order to have 95% power to detect an effect size of 0.70 (ηP2) at alpha level 0.01 for the emotion*spatial interaction. Moreover, 11 participants are required in the NT group in order to have 95% power to detect an effect size of 0.53 (ηP2) for the emotion* kinematic interaction at alpha level 0.01. 

These power analyses were completed on the basis of data from a previous pilot study which investigated controls. It is probable that there will be greater variation in the ASD group. Therefore the present study will exceed the sample sizes generated in these power calculations to account for greater variance in the ASD group. Beyond this, Button and colleagues (2013) argue that effect size estimates are commonly inflated (“the winners curse”), and argue that power calculations are likely to be “extremely optimistic”. To guard against the winners curse we have increased our sample size to almost triple the outcome of the largest sample size generated (30 in each group, N=60).

question.value:
In this study, the manipulated variables are: 

(1)	Group membership – Participants will be divided into two groups, those with a diagnosis of ASD, and neurotypicals
(2)	Emotion: In the perception task, participants will view dynamic PLF stimuli created by filming actors displaying happy, angry and sad emotions while reading sentences aloud.
(3)	Kinematic and spatial level: For each of the target emotions, there are 9 different PLF stimuli manipulations. These stimuli exist at three different spatial (50% facial movement-S1, 100% facial movement-S2, and 150% facial movement- S3) and three different kinematic (at 50% speed -K1, at 100% speed -K2 and at 150% speed-K3) levels. The spatial and kinematic manipulations are combined resulting in 9 manipuations per emotion (e.g. (1) S1, K1, (2) S2, K1, (3) S3, K1, (4) S1, K2, (5) S2, K2, (6) S3, K2, (7) S1, K3, (8), S2, K3, (9) S3, K3).

Measured variables
This study aims to compare the facial expression recognition ability of autistic and neurotypical individuals. Moreover, this study is investigating the contribution of alexithymia to emotion recognition. Hence the measured variables are:

(1) Facial Expression Emotion intensity ratings. For each PLF stimulus, participants will make judgements about how intensely happy, angry and sad the PLF they were shown was. Participants will make these ratings on three respective visual analogue scales from 0 (not at all displaying the emotion) to 10 (very much displaying the emotion) for all three target emotions. These ratings will be used to calculate facial expression recognition accuracy as described in the indices section below. 
(2) Facial Expression Naturalness ratings. For each PLF stimulus, participants will judge how natural the expression of the PLF they were shown was. Participants will make these ratings on a visual analogue scale from 0 (not at all natural) to 10 (very much natural).
(3) Alexithymia scores. The 20- item Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS;Bagby, Parker & Taylor, 1994) will be used to measure Alexithymia.
(4) Control variables. Participants will be matched on age and non-verbal reasoning.

Facial Expression Recognition Accuracy Scores (FERAS). FERAS are calculated as the mean intensity rating of the two incorrect target emotions for a PLF stimulus (e.g. the mean of happy and sad ratings for an angry PLF) subtracted from the intensity rating of a stimulus’ target emotion (e.g. angry rating for an angry PLF). This will be calculated across all participants for all PLFs.

ANOVAs: In order to replicate the findings of Sowden et al., (under review), a 3x3x3 repeated measures ANOVA will be conducted using the control data. This ANOVA will have the factors emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus kinematic level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3), and will be conducted with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. Post-hoc analyses will be completed with individual t-tests that are corrected to adjust for multiple comparisons.

In order to compare the facial expression recognition ability of ASD and neurotypical individuals, a mixed 2x3x3x3 ANOVA with the factors group (ASD vs. control), emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus speed level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3), will be conducted with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. Once again, post-hoc analyses will be completed using with individual t-tests that are corrected to adjust for multiple comparisons.

Multiple Regression Analysis: Data will be analysed using multiple regression analyses across both groups. This regression will use facial expression recognition accuracy as the DV. The predictor variables that will be included in the regression are age, gender, non-verbal reasoning score, AQ scores and TAS scores.

q18.value: In the instance that the data violates any assumptions of the planned statistical analyses, standard transformations will be completed to ensure the data can be analysed with the aforementioned parametric tests.

q19.value:
The majority of the specified tests will use two-tailed analyses with a p =.05 significance threshold to determine whether to accept or reject the null hypothesis. The tests that are based on replicating the findings of Sowden et al., (under review) will be conducted using one-tailed analyses with a p = .1 significance threshold to determine whether to accept or reject the null hypothesis. These are:

(3x3x3 ANOVA on control data: An interaction between emotion and spatial level such that facial expression recognition accuracy will be enhanced at the S3 level (relative to the S1 and S2 level) for the happy and angry expressions, but lower for sad expressions (as sad expressions with increased movement may appear angry) In contrast, facial expression recognition accuracy will be enhanced at the S1 level for sad expression, but diminished for happy and angry expressions (as sad expressions with less movement look more intensely sad leading to enhanced accuracy). An interaction between emotion and kinematic level such that facial expression recognition accuracy will be elevated at the K3 level (relatvie to K1 and K2) for happy and angry expressions, but lower for sad expressions (as sad expressions with increased speed may look angry). Conversely, at the K1 level (relative to K2 and K3), facial expression recognition accuracy will be elevated for sad expressions, but lower for angry and sad (as when sad expressions are slowed down they look more intensely sad).

q20.value: We will use Mahalanobis Distance to determine multivariate outliers, and any detected outliers will be excluded from the final analyses.

q21.value: If a participant is missing data within the recognition task (e.g. only completed half of the task), they will be excluded from the analysis.

q22.value: Additional analyses will be completed to compare the perception of naturalness of movement across kinematic and spatial manipulations between the ASD and control group. Two independent ANOVAs will be conducted. Firstly, the effects of group (ASD vs. control), emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad) and kinematic manipulation (50% vs. 100% vs. 150%) upon perceived naturalness of movement will be tested using 2x3x3 mixed ANOVA (with group as the between-subjects factor, and emotion and kinematic manipulation as the within-subjects factor). Secondly, the effects of group (ASD vs. control), emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad) and spatial manipulation (50% vs. 100% vs. 150%) upon perceived naturalness of movement will be tested. Once again, post-hoc analyses will be completed with individual t-tests that are corrected to adjust for multiple comparisons.

registration_responses.q1: Connor Keating, Sophie Sowden, Jennifer Cook
registration_responses.q2:
There are a number of hypotheses that are relevant to the upcoming study:

ANOVAs: In order to replicate the findings in Sowden et al., (under review) data from neurotpyical participants will be analysed with a repeated measures 3x3x3 ANOVA with the factors emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus kinematic level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3). This ANOVA will be run with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. We here focus our predictions on the primary effects of importance from Sowden et al., (under review). We predict an interaction between emotion and spatial level such that facial expression recognition accuracy will be enhanced at the S3 level (relative to the S1 and S2 level) for the happy and angry expressions, but lower for sad expressions (as sad expressions with increased movement may appear angry). In contrast, facial expression recognition accuracy will be enhanced at the S1 level for sad expression, but diminished for happy and angry expressions (as sad expressions with less movement look more intensely sad leading to enhanced accuracy). Furthermore, we predict an interaction between emotion and kinematic level such that facial expression recognition accuracy will be elevated at the K3 level (relatvie to K1 and K2) for happy and angry expressions, but lower for sad expressions (as sad expressions with increased speed may look angry). Conversely, we predict that at the K1 level (relative to K2 and K3), facial expression recognition accuracy will be elevated for sad expressions, but lower for angry and sad (as when sad expressions are slowed down they look more intensely sad). These predictions are made on the basis of findings from Sowden et al., (under review).

In addition, this task will bring novel insight by analysing the recognition task data with a mixed 2x3x3x3 ANOVA with the factors group (ASD vs. control), emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus kinematic level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3). This ANOVA will be run with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. In this analysis we predict a main effect of group such that the ASD group will have significantly lower facial expression recognition accuracy than controls. It is unclear whether facial expression recognition differences are due to difficulties processing spatial or kinematic properties of faces and therefore we will explore whether the group main effect is modulated by an interaction with spatial and/or kinematic level.

Mutliple Regression Analysis: The facial expression recognition data will be analysed using a multiple regression analysis across both groups. We hypothesize that alexithymic traits will account for more variance than autistic traits with respect to facial expression recognition accuracy.

registration_responses.q6.question:
This study employs a mixed design with a between-subjects factor of ASD diagnosis (ASD diagnosis or neurotypical) and where all participants will participate in every condition of the independent variables. Participants will complete all of the following tasks online in light of the recent COVID-19 outbreak.
 
First participants will complete various questionnaires including the Autism Quotient (AQ; Baron-Cohen, et al., 2006), and the Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS; Bagby, et al., 1994). In addition, an ADOS-2 assessment will be completed only in the ASD group to verify ASD diagnosis. 

Next, participants will complete the facial expression recognition task. This involves participants rating PLF (point-light face) stimuli (created from 4 actors verbalising sentences whilst posing emotional states) on a visual analogue scale according to how happy, angry and sad they appear. These PLFs vary in emotion (happy, angry and sad), and have been adapted to achieve three spatial movement levels (S1 – 50% spatial movement; S2 – 100%; S3 – 150%) and three kinematic levels (K1 – 50% speed; K2 – 100%; K3 – 150%) resulting in 9 manipulations per emotion (e.g. (1) S1, K1, (2) S2, K1, (3) S3, K1, (4) S1, K2, (5) S2, K2, (6) S3, K2, (7) S1, K3, (8), S2, K3, (9) S3, K3). This task was developed by Sowden et al. (under review).

Participants will then complete another shorter facial expression recognition task. This involves participants rating PLF stimuli according to how natural the facial expressions appear on a visual analogue scale. These PLFs vary in emotion (happy, angry and sad) and have been adapted to include three spatial movment levels (S1 – 50% spatial movement; S2 – 100%; S3 – 150). After rating face stimuli that vary in their spatial movement, participants will be shown PLFs displaying the target emotions that have been adapted to include three kinematic levels (K1 – 50% speed; K2 – 100%; K3 – 150%). These are included for exploratory purposes due to reports of differences in naturalness ratings between autistic and neurotypical participants (Sato et al., 2013). 

Finally, participants will complete the Matrix Reasoning Item Bank (MaRs-IB; Chierchia et al. 2019), which assesses non-verbal reasoning.

All recruitment material contains information about the study, reimbursement and inclusion criteria. Informed consent will be given by all participants, who will be reimbursed with payment at a rate of £10 per hour. Participants will make these ratings on three respective visual analogue scales from 0 (not at all displaying the emotion) to 10 (very much displaying the emotion) for all three target emotions. These ratings will be used to calculate facial expression recognition accuracy as described in the indices section below. 
(2) Facial Expression Naturalness ratings. For each PLF stimulus, participants will judge how natural the expression of the PLF they were shown was. Participants will make these ratings on a visual analogue scale from 0 (not at all natural) to 10 (very much natural).
(3) Alexithymia scores. The 20- item Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS;Bagby, Parker & Taylor, 1994) will be used to measure Alexithymia.
(4) Control variables. Participants will be matched on age and non-verbal reasoning.
registration_responses.q16.question: Facial Expression Recognition Accuracy Scores (FERAS). FERAS are calculated as the mean intensity rating of the two incorrect target emotions for a PLF stimulus (e.g. the mean of happy and sad ratings for an angry PLF) subtracted from the intensity rating of a stimulus’ target emotion (e.g. angry rating for an angry PLF). This will be calculated across all participants for all PLFs.
registration_responses.q17.question:
ANOVAs: In order to replicate the findings of Sowden et al., (under review), a 3x3x3 repeated measures ANOVA will be conducted using the control data. This ANOVA will have the factors emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus kinematic level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3), and will be conducted with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. Post-hoc analyses will be completed with individual t-tests that are corrected to adjust for multiple comparisons.

In order to compare the facial expression recognition ability of ASD and neurotypical individuals, a mixed 2x3x3x3 ANOVA with the factors group (ASD vs. control), emotion (happy vs. angry vs. sad), stimulus spatial level (S1 vs. S2 vs. S3), and stimulus speed level (K1 vs. K2 vs. K3), will be conducted with facial expression recognition accuracy as the dependent variable. Once again, post-hoc analyses will be completed using with individual t-tests that are corrected to adjust for multiple comparisons.

Multiple Regression Analysis: Data will be analysed using multiple regression analyses across both groups. This regression will use facial expression recognition accuracy as the DV. The predictor variables that will be included in the regression are age, gender, non-verbal reasoning score, AQ scores and TAS scores.

attributes.title: Explanations in criminal/legal reasoning
attributes.description: Experiment 5 in project exploring people's explanatory preferences in a legal domain

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: Textual responses might be coded and analysed in order to systematically evaluate people's reasoning underlying their choices.

sample.value: We seek a sample size of 70 participants in each condition, so a total sample size of 280 participants (post-exclusions)

analyses.value:
A mixed methods ANOVA will be carried out to assess differences in the ratings within subjects (after viewing 0 vs. 1 vs. 2 closing arguments) and between subjects (between the motive-opportunity ordering conditions). 

Furthermore, independent samples t-tests will be used to explore between-condition differences in the ratings of each dimension (eg. persuasiveness) of the closing arguments. Paired-samples t-tests will be used to explore within-condition differences in the ratings of the two closing arguments each participant views.

outliers.value: No outliers will be excluded. Participants will be excluded if and only if they demonstrate a clear failure to understand the task. Note that we do not anticipate having to include any participants.

dependent.value: We have two dependent variables. The primary DV is the ratings of the likelihood of guilt (continuous scale 0-10). The secondary DV is the ratings pertaining to the closing arguments on believability, persuasiveness, believability, completeness (7-point Likert-scale statements ranging from 'strongly disagree' to 'strongly agree').

conditions.value: A 2 x 2 design will be used (four conditions). All participants will see the prosecution's closing argument first, followed by the defence's closing argument. We will systematically vary whether these arguments contain information on motive or opportunity. One condition will see Prosecution 'motive' closing statement followed by Defense 'motive' closing statement ; one condition will see Prosecution 'motive' closing statement followed by Defense 'opportunity' closing statement; one condition will see Prosecution 'opportunity' closing statement followed by Defense 'motive' closing statement and finally one condition will see Prosecution 'opportunity' closing statement followed by Defense 'opportunity' closing statement.

hypothesis.value:
In this project, we are asking if people have a general 'purpose bias' in various stages of the legal/criminal process. In this particular study, we are asking whether this 'purpose bias' is present at later stages of the legal/criminal process; namely, when evaluating closing arguments in criminal trials. 

Participants will read a brief (4-5 sentence) introduction to a criminal case and asked to provide an initial rating of likelihood of guilt of the defendant.They will then be tasked as a member of the jury in the trial relevant to the case briefing they received and asked to read the prosecution's closing argument (either comprising of information pertaining to motive or opportunity) followed by the defence's closing argument (either comprising of information pertaining to motive or opportunity).

 After reading each argument participants will update their likelihood of guilt ratings and will be asked to evaluate each closing argument on four dimensions: believability, persuasiveness, completeness and convincingness by indicating how much they agree or disagree with certain statements.

We expect participants' guilt ratings to increase significantly more after viewing the closing argument containing information pertaining to motive first (compared to the closing argument containing information pertaining to opportunity first). In addition, we might also expect that participants’ final guilt ratings will decrease significantly more when the defence’s argument contains information pertaining to opportunity rather than motive. 

In regard to the Likert-scale ratings, we might expect the ratings to indicate that the prosecutions’ closing argument is more persuasive and convincing when it comprises of motive information and conversely that the defence’s closing argument is more persuasive and convincing when it comprises of opportunity information.

attributes.title: Coronavirus Risk Perception
attributes.description: Covid-19 is a highly-contagious, novel coronavirus disease that originated as a local outbreak in Wuhan (Hubei, China) in December 2019 and is now classified as a world pandemic by the WHO with over half a million confirmed cases in the United States (US) at the time of this preregistration (Dong, Du, & Gardner, 2020). Risk perceptions play a crucial role in preventative health behavior (Ferrer & Klein, 2015) and there is vast evidence that individuals express optimistic bias, an underestimation of health risks in comparison to others (Helweg-Larsen & Shepperd, 2001). This study will explore risk perceptions for coronavirus in real-time as the pandemic unfolds among a representative sample of US adults recruited via Prolific. Participants will respond to Qualtrics surveys across two time points, baseline (Time 1) and two weeks later (Time 2). We will examine how risk perceptions vary based on individual differences and across time, how risk perceptions and socially-informed cognitions (descriptive norms, prototypes) relate to precautionary behaviors for the coronavirus, and how community-level variables (state, severity of outbreak), political beliefs, and gender-related beliefs inform coronavirus risk perception and related behavioral pathways.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
For analyses on behaviors, we will examine whether receiving the flu vaccination during the 2019-20 flu season is a putative covariate.

For analyses examining the relation of personal risk and optimistic bias to behavior, we will examine whether current stay-at-home orders or classifying oneself as vulnerable to the coronavirus is a putative covariate/moderator.

We will explore sensitivity analyses based on location (e.g., rural versus urban areas, states with stricter or more permissive orders focused on prevention, states or areas with severe outbreaks). 

We will conduct exploratory analyses on intention to receive a coronavirus vaccine if it becomes available in the future.

Based on the rapid-changing nature of the pandemic, we may examine between-participant differences using a pre- post- design based on unknown major events (e.g., comparing personal risk for participants who filled out the survey on days before or after, for example, President Trump dies from coronavirus; comparing reported social distance behavior on days before or after, for example, a nationwide enforced stay-at-home mandate). 

References in this preregistration:

Chauvin, B. (2018). Individual differences in the judgment of risks: Sociodemographic characteristics, cultural orientation, and level of expertise. In M. Raue, E. Lermer, & B. Streicher (Eds.), Psychological perspectives on risk and risk analysis: Theory, models, and applications (pp. 37-61). Cham, Switzerland: Springer.

Dong, E., Du, H., & Gardner, L. (2020). An interactive web-based dashboard to track COVID-19 in real time. The Lancet Infectious Diseases, S1473309920301201. https://doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(20)30120-1

Ferrer, R. A., & Klein, W. M. (2015). Risk perceptions and health behavior. Current Opinion in Psychology, 5, 85-89.

Gibbons, F. X., Gerrard, M., Stock, M. L., & Finneran, S. D. (2015). The prototype/willingness model. In M. Connor & P. Norman (Eds.), Predicting health behavior: Research and practice with social cognition models (3rd ed., pp. 189–224). Cambridge, United Kingdom: Cambridge University Press.

Helweg-Larsen, M., & Shepperd, J. A. (2001). Do moderators of the optimistic bias affect personal or target risk estimates? A review of the literature. Personality and Social Psychology Review, 5(1), 74-95. 

Lau, J. T., Kim, J. H., Tsui, H. Y., & Griffiths, S. (2007). Anticipated and current preventive behaviors in response to an anticipated human-to-human H5N1 epidemic in the Hong Kong Chinese general population. BMC Infectious Diseases, 7(1), 18. https://doi.org/10.1186/1471-2334-7-18

Miller, S., Yardley, L., & Little, P. (2012). Development of an intervention to reduce transmission of respiratory infections and pandemic flu: Measuring and predicting hand-washing intentions. Psychology, Health & Medicine, 17(1), 59–81. https://doi.org/10.1080/13548506.2011.564188

Permut, S., Fisher, M., & Oppenheimer, D. M. (2019). TaskMaster: A tool for determining when subjects are on task. Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science, 2(2), 188–196. https://doi.org/10.1177/2515245919838479

Wise, T., Zbozinek, T. D., Michelini, G., & Hagan, C. C. (2020). Changes in risk perception and protective behavior during the first week of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States. Preprint https://psyarxiv.com/dz428/

sample.value:
A power analysis conducted in G*Power yields a sample size of 254 with the following settings: power at 95%, the alpha level at 0.05, a small to medium effect size (~ f = .10), and selecting a multiple regression with 10 predictors.
 	
We will sample 1000 participants at Time 1 and expect that 65% will participate at Time 2 (N=650). Further, we expect to exclude about 20% who will have had the coronavirus (even though we’ve asked those participants to not take the survey, N=520), and exclude about 10% who failed the attention check or were outliers in how long they took to complete the survey (N=468). We anticipate that some analyses will require us to compare samples from regions with a severe versus less severe coronavirus outbreak.

analyses.value: Variables will be assessed for normality and we will apply appropriate transformations or recoding based on response distributions. Bivariate associations will be explored with correlations and t-tests/ANOVAs (or non-parametric tests, depending on response distribution). Hypothesis-driven analyses will address relative putative covariates and be performed with ANOVAs and regressions. Mediation and moderation will be performed using PROCESS and cross-product interaction terms in regressions.

outliers.value:
We will explore several post-data collection exclusionary measures.

First, depending on the analysis (e.g., those involving personal risk perception), we will exclude individuals who report that they have tested positive for coronavirus or believe they have had coronavirus. However, given the fast-changing nature of the pandemic, we may include individuals in analyses if we end up with a sample that is powered enough to run comparisons between people who have or have not personally experienced the illness. Additionally, scientific consensus is still developing regarding whether individuals who have experienced and recovered from COVID-19 can be reinfected, which may influence inclusion of participants who report they have had coronavirus. 

Second, we will employ several data quality/participant attention checks including examining time spent taking the survey and eliminating outliers (e.g., individuals who complete the survey in a very short period of time), inaccurate responses on an embedded attention-check question, and quality of responses to an open-ended question at the end asking participants about what influences their perception of risk. Prior to launching the survey, we will also attempt to embed a TaskMaster code within the Qualtrics survey to determine whether participants are clicking/focusing on their screen or alternative screens and use this an additional attention check (Permut, Fisher, & Oppenheimer, 2019). Finally, we will check the correspondence of participant self-report states and their zip codes to determine whether there are discrepancies in their self-reported geography.

dependent.value:
The three central criterion variables of interest are: personal risk, optimistic bias, and precautionary behaviors. Transformations will be performed to achieve normality or variables will be recoded into categorical levels.

Personal risk and optimistic bias (adapted from Wise, Zbozinek, Michelini, & Hagan, 2020)

How likely do you think you are to become infected with the coronavirus?
How likely do you think you would be to die if you became infected with the coronavirus?
How likely do you think the average person in your state is to become infected with the coronavirus?
How likely do you think the average person in the United States is to become infected with the coronavirus?
How likely do you think the average person in your state would be to die if they became infected with the coronavirus?
How likely do you think the average person in the United States would be to die if they became infected with the coronavirus?
(0 = Very unlikely; 100 = Very likely; sliding scale)

Optimistic bias will be calculated by subtracting personal risk from the corresponding item for average person risk (state and US).

Precautionary behaviors (adapted from Lau, Kim, Tsui, & Griffiths, 2007; Miller; Yardley, & Little, 2012; Wise, Zbozinek, Michelini, & Hagan, 2020)

In the past two weeks, I have taken all precautionary measures against the coronavirus.
In the past two weeks, I have avoided close contact with all people outside my home.
In the past two weeks, I have avoided meeting up with any people in person (friends, family, etc.).
In the past two weeks, I have stayed at home nearly all the time.
In the past two weeks, I have washed my hands a great deal more than normal.
In the past two weeks, I have worn a face mask or cover every time I’ve gone outside.
In the past two weeks, I have sanitized or wiped down all my groceries.
(1 – Strongly disagree; 5 – Strongly agree; Likert scale)

hypothesis.value:
1)	Participants will have an optimistic bias regarding their coronavirus risk (participants will rate their personal risk for both getting and dying from coronavirus as less than the risk of others in their state and the US).

2)	Participants’ personal risk and optimistic bias will vary based on demographic factors.
a.	We predict that older age will associate with higher personal risk and less optimistic bias.
b.	Previous research shows that people of color, women, and less educated people express higher concern for a variety of health risks (Chauvin, 2018). We will examine these differences, however it is possible that for the coronavirus specifically this pattern will be attenuated based on local severity.
c.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining other demographic variables (e.g., sexual orientation) to see if they are related to personal risk and optimistic bias.

3)	Participants’ personal risk and optimistic bias will vary based on geography, personal experience, personal precautionary behaviors, and other risk-related cognitions.
a.	Geography: Participants in states with widespread/severe outbreaks (their perception and objective classification based on their reported zip code) will have higher personal risk and less optimistic bias.
b.	Geography: Participants in states with less widespread/severe outbreaks (compared to participants in states with more widespread/severe outbreaks) will perceive their state risk as lower than US risk.
c.	Personal experience: Participants who have close others who have been diagnosed with or died from coronavirus will have higher personal risk and less optimistic bias.
d.	Behaviors: Participants reporting greater precautionary behavior engagement (e.g., washing hands, social distancing, mask wearing) will have lower personal risk and more optimistic bias.
e.	Other risk-related cognitions: Participants with greater anticipated regret, coronavirus worry, perceived severity of coronavirus, and lower control will have higher personal risk and less optimistic bias. 
f.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining institutional trust (e.g., in state officials, US government institutions) to see if institutional trust is related to personal risk and optimistic bias.

4)	Risk perception change across time will vary. 
a.	Participants who report that the outbreak is severe at Time 1 will report greater personal risk and less optimistic bias at Time 2 (two weeks post-Time 1) than at Time 1. 
b.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining whether other risk-related cognitions are associated with change in personal risk and optimistic bias between Time 1 and Time 2.

5)	Higher personal risk perception and less optimistic bias at Time 1 will predict greater precautionary behavior at Time 2 as well as an increase in precautionary behavior from Time 1 to Time 2. This relationship will be moderated based on geography, personal experience, Time 1 personal precautionary behaviors, and other risk-related cognitions.
a.	Geography: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants living in states with widespread/severe outbreaks (their perception and objective classification).
b.	Personal experience: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants who have close others who have been diagnosed with or died from coronavirus.
c.	Behaviors: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants reporting greater engagement in Time 1 precautionary behavior.
d.	Other risk-related cognitions: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants with greater anticipated regret, coronavirus worry, perceived severity of coronavirus, and lower control.
e.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining whether institutional trust (e.g., in state officials, US government institutions) moderates the risk to behavior relation.

6)	Health-related cognitions, including socially-informed cognitions derived from the Prototype Willingness Model (descriptive norms and prototypes of precautionary behavior-adopters; Gibbons, Gerrard, Stock, & Finneran, 2015), at Time 1 will predict greater engagement in precautionary behavior at Time 2 as well as an increase in precautionary behavior from Time 1 to Time 2.
a.	While we expect precautionary behavior to be driven by personal risk and optimistic bias (see Hypothesis 5), we will conduct analyses to examine whether risk-related cognitions (greater anticipated regret, coronavirus worry, perceived severity of coronavirus, and lower control) associate with greater engagement in precautionary behavior.
b.	Participants reporting higher descriptive norms and more favorable prototypes will report greater engagement in precautionary behavior. We will conduct exploratory analyses to examine whether these relations are moderated by gender and age.
c.	We will examine whether these relations are mediated through behavioral intentions such that greater risk perceptions, descriptive norms, and more favorable prototypes are related to higher intentions, and thus, greater engagement in precautionary behavior.
d.	We will conduct other relevant exploratory moderation analyses (e.g., the norms to intention relation may be attenuated/weaker for participants living in states with severe/widespread outbreaks).

7)	Participants’ personal risk and optimistic bias will vary based on political beliefs (political orientation, support of/beliefs about President Trump, and system justification).
a.	More conservative political orientation (general, economic, social) will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias. This relation will be strongest for economic conservative political orientation.
b.	Support of President Trump (e.g., 2016 presidential vote choice, 2020 future presidential vote choice, trust of President Trump) will relate to lower personal risk and more optimistic bias.
c.	Higher system justification will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias. 

8)	Participants’ personal risk and optimistic bias will vary based on gender-related beliefs (gender role discrepancy, belief in traditional gender roles).
a.	Higher gender role discrepancy will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias.
b.	Higher belief in traditional gender roles will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias.
c.	We will conduct exploratory analyses to examine whether gender moderates these relationships.

9)	Higher gender-related beliefs will relate to less personal precautionary behavior in a moderated (by gender), mediated (through coronavirus beliefs and risk perception) pathway. 
a.	Higher gender-related beliefs will associate with coronavirus beliefs (e.g., believing that the coronavirus problems are overblown, believing that the coronavirus will negatively impact personal finances). This relationship will be moderated by gender, such that it will be stronger for men.
b.	Coronavirus beliefs will be related to lower personal risk perceptions and more optimistic bias. We will conduct exploratory analyses to examine whether gender moderates these relationships.
c.	Greater personal risk and less optimistic bias will relate to more precautionary behaviors.

We will examine these differences, however it is possible that for the coronavirus specifically this pattern will be attenuated based on local severity.
c.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining other demographic variables (e.g., sexual orientation) to see if they are related to personal risk and optimistic bias.

3)	Participants’ personal risk and optimistic bias will vary based on geography, personal experience, personal precautionary behaviors, and other risk-related cognitions.
a.	Geography: Participants in states with widespread/severe outbreaks (their perception and objective classification based on their reported zip code) will have higher personal risk and less optimistic bias.
b.	Geography: Participants in states with less widespread/severe outbreaks (compared to participants in states with more widespread/severe outbreaks) will perceive their state risk as lower than US risk.
c.	Personal experience: Participants who have close others who have been diagnosed with or died from coronavirus will have higher personal risk and less optimistic bias.
d.	Behaviors: Participants reporting greater precautionary behavior engagement (e.g., washing hands, social distancing, mask wearing) will have lower personal risk and more optimistic bias.
e.	Other risk-related cognitions: Participants with greater anticipated regret, coronavirus worry, perceived severity of coronavirus, and lower control will have higher personal risk and less optimistic bias. 
f.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining institutional trust (e.g., in state officials, US government institutions) to see if institutional trust is related to personal risk and optimistic bias.

4)	Risk perception change across time will vary. 
a.	Participants who report that the outbreak is severe at Time 1 will report greater personal risk and less optimistic bias at Time 2 (two weeks post-Time 1) than at Time 1. 
b.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining whether other risk-related cognitions are associated with change in personal risk and optimistic bias between Time 1 and Time 2.

5)	Higher personal risk perception and less optimistic bias at Time 1 will predict greater precautionary behavior at Time 2 as well as an increase in precautionary behavior from Time 1 to Time 2. This relationship will be moderated based on geography, personal experience, Time 1 personal precautionary behaviors, and other risk-related cognitions.
a.	Geography: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants living in states with widespread/severe outbreaks (their perception and objective classification).
b.	Personal experience: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants who have close others who have been diagnosed with or died from coronavirus.
c.	Behaviors: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants reporting greater engagement in Time 1 precautionary behavior.
d.	Other risk-related cognitions: The risk to behavior relation will be attenuated/weaker for participants with greater anticipated regret, coronavirus worry, perceived severity of coronavirus, and lower control.
e.	We will conduct exploratory analyses examining whether institutional trust (e.g., in state officials, US government institutions) moderates the risk to behavior relation.

6)	Health-related cognitions, including socially-informed cognitions derived from the Prototype Willingness Model (descriptive norms and prototypes of precautionary behavior-adopters; Gibbons, Gerrard, Stock, & Finneran, 2015), at Time 1 will predict greater engagement in precautionary behavior at Time 2 as well as an increase in precautionary behavior from Time 1 to Time 2.
a.	While we expect precautionary behavior to be driven by personal risk and optimistic bias (see Hypothesis 5), we will conduct analyses to examine whether risk-related cognitions (greater anticipated regret, coronavirus worry, perceived severity of coronavirus, and lower control) associate with greater engagement in precautionary behavior.
b.	Participants reporting higher descriptive norms and more favorable prototypes will report greater engagement in precautionary behavior. We will conduct exploratory analyses to examine whether these relations are moderated by gender and age.
c.	We will examine whether these relations are mediated through behavioral intentions such that greater risk perceptions, descriptive norms, and more favorable prototypes are related to higher intentions, and thus, greater engagement in precautionary behavior.
d.	We will conduct other relevant exploratory moderation analyses (e.g., the norms to intention relation may be attenuated/weaker for participants living in states with severe/widespread outbreaks).

7)	Participants’ personal risk and optimistic bias will vary based on political beliefs (political orientation, support of/beliefs about President Trump, and system justification).
a.	More conservative political orientation (general, economic, social) will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias. This relation will be strongest for economic conservative political orientation.
b.	Support of President Trump (e.g., 2016 presidential vote choice, 2020 future presidential vote choice, trust of President Trump) will relate to lower personal risk and more optimistic bias.
c.	Higher system justification will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias. 

8)	Participants’ personal risk and optimistic bias will vary based on gender-related beliefs (gender role discrepancy, belief in traditional gender roles).
a.	Higher gender role discrepancy will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias.
b.	Higher belief in traditional gender roles will associate with less personal risk and more optimistic bias.
c.	We will conduct exploratory analyses to examine whether gender moderates these relationships.

9)	Higher gender-related beliefs will relate to less personal precautionary behavior in a moderated (by gender), mediated (through coronavirus beliefs and risk perception) pathway. 
a.	Higher gender-related beliefs will associate with coronavirus beliefs (e.g., believing that the coronavirus problems are overblown, believing that the coronavirus will negatively impact personal finances). This relationship will be moderated by gender, such that it will be stronger for men.
b.	Coronavirus beliefs will be related to lower personal risk perceptions and more optimistic bias. We will conduct exploratory analyses to examine whether gender moderates these relationships.
c.	Greater personal risk and less optimistic bias will relate to more precautionary behaviors.

attributes.title: Protocol A Stakeholder Mapping and Scoping Review of Communicable Disease Prevention and Control Policy in the Republic of Ireland
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Revised protocol uploaded prior to study intitation

q1.value: Direct Replication of a research claim from Woltin et al, 2011, in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology

q3.value: We selected the claim that the detailed, concrete processing style associated with low power should facilitate empathic concern (Statement 2), which reflects "In three experiments inducing a detailed versus abstract processing style using perceptual (Experiment 1), motivational (Experiment 2), and social (Experiment 3) manipulations, we found that empathic concerns are enhanced in contexts associated with a more detailed processing style (i.e., local perceptual scope, prevention motivation, and low power, respectively)" (Statement 1), as found in the paper's abstract. The claim (from Experiment 3 in the original manuscript) is tested by an ANOVA test using the power priming condition (low/high power) as the independent variable and empathic concern as the dependent variable (Statement 3), which resulted in power priming influencing participants' empathic concern, F(1,34) = 5.76, p = .022, partial eta squared = .15 - participants reported greater empathic concern when primed with low power (Statement 4).

q4.value: Participants primed with “low power” will report greater empathic concern, as measured with the empathic concern scale.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study consists of a two group, between-subjects design with 1 factor (priming) and 2 levels (powerful or powerless).

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to either the powerful or powerless prime condition. This random assignation will be achieved through the random generation of a subject ID through the Millisecond web platform. Even-numbered subject IDs will be allocated to the powerful condition, while odd-numbered subject IDs will be allocated to the powerless condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through the online data collection platform Prolific Academic. Participants will be paid at a rate of £6 per hour. To be eligible for participation, participants must be at least 18 years old, identify as male, have at least a 90% approval rating from previous studies on Prolific, and must have English as a first language. This screening will be completed using Prolific’s automated participant screening. 

Participants will be excluded if they fail to provide full data on any of the measures, if they fail the attention or suspicion checks, or if they respond with a valid reason for exclusion of their data (see Measures below).

q13.value: To have 90% power to detect 75% of the original effect size, a sample size of 114 (57 per group) participants is required. The criteria for replication is an effect in the same direction as the original study and a p-value < 0.05. If the original result is not replicated in the first data collection, a second data collection of 138 additional participants will be carried out so that the total sample size is 252 (126 per group). If a second data collection is carried out, it will be tested if the original result replicates in the pooled sample of the first and second data collection.

q14.value:
Power calculations were done in accordance with the guidelines of the Social Sciences Replication Project (SSRP). The first round of data collection achieves 90% power to detect 75% of the original effect size. The pooled sample, if necessary after testing the effect on the first round of data collection, achieves 90% power to detect 50% of the original effect size.

The power analysis for this replication is stored in the OSF project associated with this replication attempt, in the power analysis component.

q15.value: Data collection will stop once 57 participants in each group with completed data are collected, and the analysis will be run.  If the replication is not successful, the second round of data collection will commence and will stop once 126 participants per group with completed data are collected in total (including the initial sample).

question.value: Prime condition - participants will be randomly assigned to either the powerful prime condition or the powerless prime condition.  Both are a word completion task with either dominant or submissive words, the same as used in Woltin et al. (2011).  Each list consists of 40 words, where 20 words are neutral and are the same in both lists, and 20 words correspond to either the powerful or powerless condition.

Empathic concern - after the word completion task, participants will complete the Empathic Concern Scale (ECS), which are the following 7 questions scored on a 5 point Likert scale, with 1 anchored as “does not describe me well”, and 5 as “describes me very well”.

When I see someone being taken advantage of, I feel kind of protective towards them.
When I see someone being treated unfairly, I sometimes don't feel very much pity for them.
I often have tender, concerned feelings for people less fortunate than me.
I would describe myself as a pretty soft-hearted person.
Sometimes I don't feel very sorry for other people when they are having problems.
Other people's misfortunes do not usually disturb me a great deal.
I am often quite touched by things that I see happen.
An ECS score will be computed by taking the average score of the Likert items (items 2, 5, and 6 are reverse-coded), as in the original study.
As in the original study, an ANOVA will be conducted with one predictor (prime condition) with 2 levels (powerful vs powerless) and one dependent variable: the ECS.

q20.value: There is no expected transformation required for this analysis, other than calculating overall ECS scores (detailed previously).

q21.value: The replication will be considered successful if there is an effect in the same direction of the original study with a p-value < 0.05.  For this replication, it is predicted that participants primed with low power will show higher empathic concern.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail to provide complete data for all measures, or if they fail the attention or suspicion checks. Participants will also be excluded if they indicate that their data should be excluded from analyses (and provide a valid reason for doing so).

q23.value: If subjects fail to provide complete data on all measures, then they will be excluded from analyses (and resampled accordingly).

q24.value:
We will conduct a mixed-effects meta-analysis of the effect using pooled data from the original study and our replication (using the lme4 R package), ECS scores as the dependent variable, prime condition as a fixed effect, and study (i.e., original vs. replication) as a random effect in order to determine whether an overall effect is present. 

In the event that no effect is found in the replication/meta-analysis analyses, it may be of interest to quantify evidence for the null by calculating Bayes Factors for both the original and replication effects, as well as using Bayesian meta-analysis in brms to quantify overall evidence for the null.
